Order below exh. 1 in Criminal M.A. No. 158/2019 CNR No. MHPU01­000611 ­2019 
---header-ends---
1. Perused application and say exh.5. Heard both the learned Counsel. 2. By this application under Section 439 of Cr.P.C., applicant /unnamed­accused –Sagar Maruti Khaire of Crime No. 219/2018 registered on 07.08.2018 with Bundgarden Police Station, Pune, under Sections 307, 143, 147, 148 r.w.s. 149 of Indian Penal Code, under Section 4/27 of the Arms Act and under Section 37(1)(3) r.w.s. 135 of the Bombay Police Act, seek bail. It is objected over nature of offence and ongoing investigation. 
---background-ends---
3. The learned Counsel for the applicant has submitted that since only two accused are apprehended from the scene of offence, no offence of rioting is made out. The applicant is in custody since 23.12.2018 between the period, investigation against two accused is completed, final report is furnished against them, warranting no custodial interrogation. Duo co­accused in Cri.M.A. No. 4073/2018 are released on bail on 31.10.2018. Thus, the applicant deserves rule of parity. 
---argument-ends---
4. On the contrary, learned AGP submitted that the investigation is going on and identification parade is to be arranged. 
---argument-ends---
5. On going through record, it is conspicuous that on 06.08.2018 at about 2.30 a.m. informant had been to Railway Station. He was telephoned by grandson of his aunt. While they were waiting for vehicle, one two­wheeler having two pillion riders arrived, one of them claimed Rs. 200/­ from the informant. He ignored him. Over which two of five ransacked the informant of cash amount and golden chain and fled away. Thus, there was involvement of trio unnamed assailants on public road. Till date no identification parade seems to be scheduled. 
---argument-ends---
6. The learned Counsel for the applicant has relied upon pronouncement between Sanjay Chandra V/s. Central Bureau of Investigation Vinod Goenka V/s. Central Bureau of Investigation, Gautam Doshi V/s. Central Bureau of Investigation, Hari Nair V/s. Central Bureau of Investigation, Surendra Pipara V/s. Central Bureau of Investigation, AIR 2012 Supreme Court 830, wherein it is observed that the object of bail is generally to secure appearance of accused person at crime. His object is neither punitive nor preventative. The grant of bail is the rule. And, committal to­ jail, and exception. Refusal of bail is restriction on personal liberty of individual, granted by Article 21 of the Constitution of India. 
---argument-ends---
7. In view of above, applicant deserves parity. Hence, the order : 
---argument-ends---
ORDER 1. Application stands allowed as under:­ Applicant be released on furnishing P.R.Bond of Rs. 25,000/­ together with one or two solvent sureties of like amount on following conditions. a] He shall not tamper prosecution witnesses. b] He shall not leave India sans the permission of this Court. C] He shall attend Police Station on each Monday between 11.00 a.m. to 1.00 p.m. for two months or until furnishing of final report, whichever is earlier. 2. Bail before committing Court. Pune ( Vikas S. Kulkarni) January 19, 2019 Additional Sessions Judge, 
---order-ends---
